Revenue, also referred to as "receipts," can be classified into two major categories:

∑ Budget receipts are collections from the public that result from the exercise of the federal government's sovereign powers. These collections consist mainly of tax revenue, revenue from court fines, certain licenses, and deposits of earnings by the Federal Reserve System. 
∑ Offsetting collections differ from budget receipts in that they result from activities that are of a business-type or market-oriented nature, not the exercise of the federal government's sovereign powers. An example of an offsetting collection would be park entrance fees collected by the National Park Service.

A fund that conducts continuing cycles of business-like activity, in which the fund charges for the sale of products or services and uses the proceeds to finance its spending, usually without requirement for annual appropriations.
The Risk Management Agency administers the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation and provides risk management information and services to farmers and producers.
The funds in this account are provided by non-federal interests to cover some or all of the costs for the study, design, construction, and operation and maintenance of water resources projects.

Rural Development offers loans, grants and loan guarantees to support essential services such as housing, economic development, health care, first responder services and equipment and water, electric and communications infrastructure.
The Rural Housing Service provides grants and loans for housing and community facilities in rural areas of the U.S.
The Rural Utilities Service provides funding for the development of rural utilities infrastructure such as water, waste management, power, and telecommunications.

The Securities and Exchange Commission oversees securities exchanges, securities brokers and dealers, investment advisors, and mutual funds in an effort to promote fair dealing, the disclosure of important market information, and to prevent fraud.

The Social Security Program provides workers and their families with retirement, disability, and survivors insurance benefits. Workers earn these benefits by paying into the system during their working years. Social Security typically refers to a combination of two funds: the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance (OASI) Trust Fund and the Disability Insurance (DI) Trust Fund. OASDI is a common abbreviation of the combined funds.

term: Social Security ñ Disability Insurance Trust Fund
definition: The Disability Insurance (DI) Trust Fund is part of the Social Security Program and pays cash benefits to eligible individuals who are unable to work because of medical conditions and certain family members of such eligible individuals. DI is financed primarily by payroll taxes and income taxes on benefits. Another source of funding is interest credited on Treasury securities held in the DI Trust Fund. DI was established on August 1, 1956.

term: Social Security ñ Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund
definition: The Old-Age and Survivors Insurance (OASI) Trust Fund is part of the Social Security Program and pays cash retirement benefits to eligible retirees and their eligible dependents and survivors. OASI is financed primarily by payroll taxes and income taxes on benefits. Another source of funding is interest credited on Treasury securities held in the OASI Trust Fund. OASI was established on January 1, 1940.

The Social Security Administration assigns Social Security numbers, and administers the Social Security retirement, survivors, and disability insurance programs. They also administer the Supplemental Security Income program for the aged, blind, and disabled.

In the auction, TV broadcasters could voluntarily give up their current broadcast channel in exchange for a share of the proceeds from an auction of their channel to commercial wireless service providers to expand mobile broadband services.

Through these grants, the Environmental Protection Agency and its state and tribal partners will advance collective priorities to deliver environmental and public health results across the nation.
Financial aid includes grants, scholarships, work-study jobs, and loans to help pay for college or career school.

Sub Account Code (SUB) is a component of the TAS that identifies a Treasury-defined subdivision of a Federal Account (AID + MAIN). Most Federal Accounts do not have subdivisions. 000 is the default SUB; if 000 is the only SUB under a given Federal Account, it has not been subdivided.

A sub-award is an agreement that a prime recipient makes with another entity to perform a portion of their award. On our website, these recipients are known as sub-recipients. Sub-awards might also be referred to as a sub-contract or a sub-grant.

A company, organization, individual, or government entity (i.e., state, local, tribal, or foreign) that receives funding from another recipient of federal funds (a prime recipient), rather than directly from the U.S. government. The sub-recipient may be a sub-contractor or a sub-grantee. For example, the Dept. of Transportation awards Bridge Company A a bridge construction contract. Bridge Company A needs Bridge Company B to supply the steel, so Bridge Company A awards Bridge Company B a sub-award. Bridge Company B is the sub-contractor. On the grants side, University A receives an R&D grant from the National Science Foundation. University A needs University B to perform the initial step in the research, so University A awards University B a sub-award. University B is the sub-grantee.

When the government makes a direct loan or guarantees a loan, it expects the loan to be repaid. However, for any given loan program (e.g., student loans, small business loan guarantees) some individual loans are not repaid. Subsidy cost is the governmentís way to estimate--based on historical default rates and other factors--a loanís likely cost to the government. Subsidy cost is computed as a percentage of the loan value, and does not include administrative costs. 

While the award amount for a grant or contract is the amount that the recipient gets, for a loan, the award amount is the subsidy cost. This is because the subsidy cost is the actual cost to the government (estimated).

Treasury and OMB assign a code to each appropriation, receipt, or fund account. This code is similar to a bank account number. It helps identify financial transactions in the federal government. It also aids in reporting accuracy. TAS are sometimes referred as ëprogram sourceí in legislation. On this website, we group each set of Treasury Accounts that share an Agency Identifier and Main Account Code into a "Federal Account". 

Seven components make up the TAS:

- Allocation Transfer Agency Identifier (ex. 089)
- Agency Identifier (ex. 020)
- Beginning Period of Availability (ex. 2017)
- Ending Period of Availability (ex. 2018)
- Availability Type Code (used if there are not specific beginning/ending years) (ex. X)
- Main Account Code (ex. 0114)
- Sub Account Code (ex. 000)

Example TAS:

- 089-020-2017/2018-0114-000
- 089-020-2017/2017-0114-000
- 089-020-X-0114-000

Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) provide protection against inflation. The principal of a TIPS increases with inflation and decreases with deflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index. When a TIPS matures, you are paid the adjusted principal or original principal, whichever is greater. TIPS pay interest twice a year, at a fixed rate. The rate is applied to the adjusted principal; so, like the principal, interest payments rise with inflation and fall with deflation.
A type of account for revenue or offsetting revenue dedicated to specific purposes and the spending of that revenue. Some revolving funds are designated as trust funds.
The Army Corps of Engineers provides public engineering services in peace and war to strengthen national security, energize the economy, and reduce risks from disasters.
The U.S. Coast Guard safeguards the maritime interests of the United States and the environment around the world.
Customs and Border Protection prevents people from entering the country illegally, or bringing anything harmful or illegal into the United States.
The U.S. Mint produces the coins that circulate throughout the United States. They also produce special edition coins you can buy for coin collections.
The United States Secret Service is a federal law enforcement agency with headquarters in Washington, D.C., and more than 150 offices throughout the United States and abroad.

The mission of the United States Tax Court is to provide a national forum to expeditiously resolve disputes between taxpayers and the Internal Revenue Service while carefully considering the merits of each case and ensuring the uniform interpretation of the Internal Revenue Code.

Offsetting revenue that is deducted from the Government-wide totals for budget authority and outlays instead of being offset against a specific agency and function. It is offset against spending, rather than added to revenue. Offsetting revenue results from business-like transactions or market-oriented activities with the public, including payments from the public in exchange for goods and services, reimbursements for damages, and gifts or donations of money to the federal government and from intragovernmental transactions.

The Unemployment Insurance (UI) Program was created in 1935 to provide income assistance to unemployed workers who lose their jobs generally through no fault of their own, and are unemployed due to a lack of suitable work. The program protects workers during temporary periods of unemployment through the provision of unemployment compensation benefits. The program is administered through a unique system of federal and state partnerships established by federal law but executed through conforming state laws by state agencies. UI is financed through the collection of federal and state unemployment taxes levied on subject employers and deposited in the Unemployment Trust Fund and federal appropriations.

The Universal Service Fund is used by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to provide financial assistance to programs that promote affordable, nationwide telephone service. The FCC provides universal service support through four mechanisms: 

∑ High Cost Support Mechanism - making phone service affordable for residents in high cost areas
∑ Low Income Support Mechanism - assisting low-income customers with monthly telephone charges and set-up charges
∑ Rural Health Support Mechanism - allowing rural health care providers to pay rates for telecommunications services similar to those of their urban counterparts
∑ Schools and Libraries Support Mechanism - providing telecommunication services, internet access, and internal connections to eligible schools and libraries
The amount of money out of an account that has yet to be awarded or obligated (promised to be spent).

An agency defined unique record identifier that (when provided) is unique for every financial assistance action reported by that agency. USAspending.gov uses the URI as the Award ID for aggregate records.
The Veterans Health Administration provides primary care, specialized care, and related medical and social support services to American veterans.
The White House holds the executive office of the President of the United States and serves as the President's residence.
